entries.title: Thousands in Israel Protest Netanyahu’s Plans to Limit Courts
entries.description: The right-wing government’s proposals for sweeping judicial reform are viewed by critics as anti-democratic and have galvanized the opposition.

entries.title: Petr Pavel and Andrej Babis to Face Off In Czech Republic Presidential Race
entries.description: Both candidates, Petr Pavel and Andrej Babis, are expected to foster closer ties to the West.

entries.title: The Saturday morning attack on Kyiv appeared to best the air-raid warning system.
China Reports Nearly 60,000 Covid Deaths Since Lifting Restrictions
entries.description: The unexpected disclosure was made as the country faces mounting criticism for providing unreliable data on its latest coronavirus outbreak.

entries.title: Cinema Studies
entries.description: Awards season has begun. It’s time to cram.

entries.title: The Dessert-First Author Whose Books Defined Canada’s Treats
entries.description: Jean Paré, the prolific, self-published cookbook writer, died last month in Alberta. Her unfussy recipes found an audience with millions of Canadians.

entries.title: As Russians Steal Ukraine’s Art, They Attack Its Identity, Too
entries.description: Russian forces have looted tens of thousands of pieces, including avant-garde oil paintings and Scythian gold. Experts say it is the biggest art heist since the Nazis in World War II, intended to strip Ukraine of its cultural heritage.

entries.title: Hunting for Truffles Is a Perilous Pursuit, Especially for the Dogs Who Dig
entries.description: Truffles are big business, and some are trying to take out the competition by poisoning the dogs that accompany those known as “truffle hunters.”

entries.title: Cooperation on Climate Is Emerging in the Middle East
entries.description: After the Abraham Accords, partnerships between companies in Israel and Arab countries have led to the kinds of initiatives that will be on the Davos agenda.

entries.title: Ecuador Tried to Curb Drilling and Protect the Amazon. The Opposite Happened.
entries.description: A novel idea to leave the country’s vast oil reserves in the ground fizzled for lack of international support. Now, struggling under painful debt, the government wants to expand drilling in the rainforest.

entries.title: Davos Is a Winter Haven, Even With the Crowds
entries.description: Many tourist spots are shut down or blocked off during the World Economic Forum, yet there’s still plenty to do amid the clear air and mountain vistas.

entries.title: A United Europe Weathers Crises, but Deeper Challenges Remain
entries.description: Differences on NATO and E.U. enlargement, energy and climate, and relationships with the United States, China, Russia and Ukraine will prime Davos talks.

entries.title: The War in Ukraine Upended Energy Markets. What Does That Mean for the Climate?
entries.description: Almost a year after Russia launched its invasion, assessing the impact on the oil industry and greenhouse gas goals is not so simple.

entries.title: World Economic Forum in Davos Confronts a New Order
entries.description: The Covid-19 pandemic, invasion of Ukraine, trend toward autocracy and economic inequalities challenge the World Economic Forum’s relevance.

entries.title: As Humanitarian Crises Escalate, So Do Demands to End Them
entries.description: David Miliband, head of the International Rescue Committee, says the global refugee crisis “is manageable, not insoluble.”

entries.title: Explosions Ring Out in Kyiv After Days of Relative Calm
entries.description: Russian forces have targeted Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, and other cities with missile and drone attacks off-and-on for months, devastating the power grid and forcing rolling blackouts.

entries.title: German Village at Center of a Fight Over Coal and Climate Is Cleared Out
entries.description: For years, activists tried to save tiny Lützerath from being razed to make way for the expansion of an open-pit coal mine. This past week, the police moved them out.

entries.title: Iran Executes Alireza Akbari, Ex-Official Accused of Spying
entries.description: Alireza Akbari, previously a senior military and defense official, had moved to Britain a decade ago. He had been detained since 2019.

entries.title: Bolsonaro Faces Investigation for Inspiring Brazil’s Capital Riot
entries.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court said it would investigate Jair Bolsonaro, the country’s former president, for inspiring the mob that stormed the nation’s halls of power on Sunday.

entries.title: Biden Administration Faces Resistance to Plan to Sell F-16s to Turkey
entries.description: The State Department has contacted Congress about major arms deals for Turkey and Greece, but a prominent senator is strongly opposed to the Ankara sale.

entries.title: No Increased Stroke Risk Linked to Pfizer’s Covid Boosters, Federal Officials Say
entries.description: An uptick hinted at in surveillance data was a mirage, the officials said.

entries.title: How a Mob Tried to Oust Brazil’s Lula
entries.description: The storming of Brazil’s capital failed to overthrow the elected government. But an examination of the attack reveals how vulnerable Latin America’s largest democracy is to extremism.

entries.title: Peter Grose, Veteran Foreign Correspondent, Dies at 88
entries.description: His career with The New York Times took him to Saigon and Moscow. He drew on that experience later to write several well-received books.
